intro: Rubus microphyllus var. incisus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved blackberry, is a shrub native to the western United States. It is characterized by its small, elliptical leaves with serrated margins, which give it its scientific name. The plant produces small, dark red berries that are typically edible and have a tart flavor. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal areas and open woodlands. Its botanical features make it an important species in local ecosystems and a subject of interest for horticultural study.
